35357356.review: I really like this game but theres problems this game is plagued by. First off is Map design. There is some maps which really shouldnt be in the game. Its those pesky square formed maps. More precisely its those with sharp angles between planes. Its nice that the edges are soft but it doesnt really solve the problem. When you use a camera which is using perspective projection theres bound to be angled planes which cant be shown. That is fine as long as they arent adjacent to the plane you are on.  Because that creates situation where you go from one plane to another and get insta killed from enemies who you couldnt see or predict they were there. For example I shot to plane I plan to go to and I expect there arent any there but right when I go there spawns one and I get instakilled. This is the second problem spawning enemies. This is less of a problem and more of a difficult aspect of the game. The problem is that enemies spawn and you happened to ignore it and where were it spawned and got killed. Its a bad feeling knowing enemies can spawn right under you and you cant help it for example if you get swarmed or something else. Luckily you can deal with it with a limited blast. I think the better solution would be to make it not possible for example by delaying or make the spawn pushable. If you think this is wrong tell me why? If you are of the same mind tell me if there is something else which is also bothering you?

35037225.review:
Geometry Wars; ah, memories back on the Wii is when I first played it. I thought it was mostly a casual shooter about math. Yknow. Childlike innocence. And then I got home and played it. For the most part, I was right. It is a pretty simple game about shooting geometric shapes, but it was really fun. Now for this game? This game feels like..like a bit of a rushed one.

I'll give it that it LOOKS beautiful. the game is one that uses a bit of wireframe-style artstyle in combination with calling itself geometry wars, it just feels like that combination was brilliant.

In the Wii version of Geometry wars, called Galaxies, you traveled around various solar systems to different planets and suns, fighting enemies for a big score on them with different types of drone functions you could upgrade. Now, Dimensions adds a bit to the drones, giving them super moves; these add a different ability along with the passive effect, such as firing missiles for a small time or becoming a black hole to suck all the enimies in range. For the levels, instead of various planets with levels, you've got kind of an adventure-style, liner path through the game, with bosses at various points.

Now, the addition of bosses was cool, and the linear story-like gameplay is neat, but there are two other modes that have this aspect, but increase the difficulty a bit; Hardcore, and Ultimate. With Ultimate it's a little different, and you usually have less amounts to use your super-powered drone ability, and Hardcore is where you have no drone. But..really..these are just modes that could have been switched with a button, or even more levels on Adventure, just harder difficulty. It's seerate menus that make the game SEEM like it's longer than it is.

That's not to say I didn't have a blast trying to beat all the bosses and get 3 stars on each level; I'm still working on getting the stars, but my idsue is the AMOUNT of levels. There's only so much I can play on it, and each level has a simple objective; usually just survive and get a high score. There's 110 levels to beat, but after each end boss of each mode, the end end boss, a strip of lined color acts like I can keep going; like there's more secrets, but having me get ALL the stars just to see that? I'm an avid player of this game, but it's difficult to do.

Onto the ship..The ship got a downgrade. Now, it always shot in 2 little tiny peashooter shots, then it got an upgrade to shoot more, usually either in a spread or machinegun-like fire. Now it only shoots 3, has a somewhat larger spead, with the introduction of 'super states' which include both the time-based switching or the weapon from the other games, alomg with new ones, but here's my problem; THE WEAPON DOESN'T STAY. It's a time-based ability, and this ability isn't allowed on bosses, severely ramping the difficulty when at the harder levels and trying to get those 3 stars. I would rather have the survival-based weapon upgrades than a 'super mode'. The ship itself is still the same while the multiplayer mode gives you a look at the others; when will we get to play single-player as ome of the others? Just gibe us a choice! I personally like player 3's ship better than the default.

All in all, I'd say it's a good game to push how good you are at twin-stick shooters. I'd see if you could het it on sale, though..it's not a lot of new content in comparison to Geometry Wars: Retro Evolved 2, and that was an Xbox 360 arcade game. It's a pretty game, yes, but that's all it's got going for it right now. Maybe 4, if it gets mde, will have more content.

33900003.review:
tl,dr: Mad fun, endlessly stimulating and worth the sticker shock, probably the best title of the franchise, disappointing soundtrack.

I was a huge fan of the Geometry Wars title for the old DS, and this pushes all of those buttons--even more successfully.  The stages are short, challenging, and significantly different from each other in most cases:  you could say that this is perfectly designed to soothingly accomodate your standard millenial gaming-induced adult ADD.

This iteration of the series has a couple of features that really extend replayability.  One:  incremental plus-up-your-drones-and-supers skinner box works exactly as planned,  Two:  knowing what I really want out of a leaderboard, it displays your Steam friends' scores -first-, so you have a sense of meaningful competition against other mere mortals (and instantly deployable bragging rights.)  Three:  I'm a sucker for three-tiered score challenges, I guess.

Anyway, it's my favorite game in the arcade genre.

Some mild criticism:  The soundtrack is extremely limited.  I like all the music I've heard, but I feel like I've only heard about four tracks, three of them very same-y.  There's one (1) boss level track, but the game seems to be pretty into its gem-themed array of bosses.  The soundtrack for the DS was excellent, so this is an unexpected letdown.

Criticism the second:  I've played about two thirds of the bosses, and they don't feel especially different from one another.  On the other hand, essential difference between levels in this game is largely a matter of different game modes and level parameters,

33841921.review: No joke, this is one of the greatest games ever made. Sorry, but it's just true. I have never played a better twin-stick shooter, and there have been scores of them ever since 1982's Robotron. There are multiple upgrades and bombs, and more modes and levels then I can beat, despite sinking countless hours into both the PC and PS3 versions of this game, so it stays fresh and is always offering you more. However, why this game is so fun, comes down to the subtle factors of gameplay; the rate of fire that you shoot, the speed of your bullets, the spread of your bullets, the feeling you get when you go "Super", and unleash bullet hell on your enemies. I could, and do, play this game for hours. Excellent controller support, and multiplayer. Oh, my only complaint would be that I wish all levels were available in co-op.

33708535.review:
I'm sure everyone is aware that there are plenty of top down arcade shooters in the market both new and old, but none of which were made like this. Unlike other arcade shooters where you play on a 2D plane, this game allows you to play on a 3D plane. This drastically changes how the game is played to where you can easily wrap around the stage without having to akwardly run into enemies and projectiles, although that can still happen but just for other reasons. You don't need to play the games before this one to like it, and you'll likely have a hard time finding them on Steam anyways. 

Although the main focus in this game is the 3D planes, you can also play on the classic 2D planes with all of the same gimics by going into classic mode. Also there is a story mode witch is just a long string of levels with certain gimics in them like: survival, enemy waves, limited ammo, time trails, ect. with most of the levels in story modes using 3D plane of some sort You earn stars based off of how well you perform in each stage with the maximum stars per stage being 3. 

These stars will add up to your overall total where you will slowely unlock boss stages that are manditory for progressing further in the mode. Once you complete story mode you will unlock a harder story mode called "Ultimate" which is essentially new stages in themselves. After that are three bonus levels basically using the gimics mentioned above with the added benefit of being an endless mode. Finally there is multiplayer where you can play online (there's nobody online) or you can play local coop with a friend and go through a string of levels like in story mode.

There is no shortage of content here and you will likely get you're money's worth if you decide to try out everything the game has to offer. This game is no doubt hard, but satisfying granted that you are good or just get better over time. This is probably one of the best arcade shotters of its genre and is a must play for someone who enjoys these kinds of arcade shooters.

33209044.review:
A great game ruined by heavily limited co-op features.

I loved the co-op mode in Geometry Wars 2 (which was sadly never released on PC). I bought this primarily to be able to play 4-player co-op again in the main game mode. Basically I wanted Geometry Wars 2.

Bafflingly, co-op in this game is only available for the "campaign", a linear series of different levels with varied game types. The campaign is alright, I suppose, but I have no interest in half of the campaign levels (and definitely not in the boss battles).

The game has modes other than "campaign", but you can only play them in single player. I just want to select the "classic" game mode and play over and over again with friends. It's such a simple, common sense thing to include that for a long time I thought I just wasn't looking in the correct place in the menus.

The gameplay is so good. It's such a shame the developers shipped it with crippled co-op, and have done nothing to improve it.

33022059.review:
Geometry Wars 3 is a very pure video game.  Aside from the wonderful graphics, very little about the game is far beyond the older games it draws inspiration from: iconic Twin-Stick Shooters like Robotron and visual design elements from Tempest.  Although GW3 does have a ton of content (including a huge free update that came out long ago, the Evolved update), you'll find all of that content involves moving your ship with the left stick and shooting all around you with the right stick.  It's a fun game but the core experience never really changes, so you can know if you'll love it or hate it just from watching the trailers.

I love it.

There are a ton of different modes and a nice mix of enemy types with several cool boss fights as well.  Almost all enemies in GW3 do not shoot at you: this is not a bullet hell.  Instead they just try to collide with you and you die in one hit.  Enemies vary in their AI / movement speed / health and are easily identified because they are distinct shapes and color-coded.  Initially the game can seem quite easy but you'll find that a lot of the endless modes can get downright insane.  Also there's a big difference between barely finishing Adventure Mode once... and 3-starring every level like I did for the achievement.  Make no mistake, you get a lot from this game for the price.  The graphics are amazing, but the music is only so-so.  I recommend turning it down and playing your own music instead: that enhanced the experience for me.  The story is... what did you actually expect a story?  You shoot everything.  Also it has multiplayer and online leaderboards for what that's worth.

32762131.review:
Wer das Ur-Geometry Wars kennt, freut sich bestimmt über diesen Titel.
Im Kern ist es dasselbe: Ein Twin-Stick shooter.
Jetzt allerdings mit einem Adventure Modus, der einem verschiedene Level und Modi hintereinander bietet. Sowie einem Klassik Modus, wo man Spiele aus dem ersten und zweiten Teil drin hat. Also die Spielmodi davon. Alles unter der neuen Optik und Musik.

Was ungewohnt ist, sind die sich bewegenden 3D Level. Wenn man nicht mehr auf einer einfachen Ebene ist, sondern die Arena eine Kugel, auf welche man Naturgemäß nicht die Rückseite sehen kann, solange man nicht dort hin fliegt, ist es etwas Eingewöhnungsbedürftigt.
Ich habe meinen Spaß daran.

Was mich nur stört, ist dieses fehlende selbst-upgraden des Schiffes. Im Erstling hat sich der Schuss vom Spieler selbstständig alle so-und-soviel Punkte geändert. Der Anfänglich war natürlich mies und dann gab es da noch zwei weitere. Jetzt fliegt man dauerhaft mit ein und demselben. Ausser man macht bestimmte Teile platt, dann bekommt man kurzzeitig einen anderen (oder man spielt im klassichen Modus).

Das einsammeln von kleinen Pünktchen um den Multiplikator zu erhöhen kann man so oder so sehen. Ich mag das nicht so wirklich. Vorteil ist natürlich, das der Punktemultiplikator sehr schnell nach oben gehen kann. Nachteil ist nur, das man ständig in die Viecher reinfliegen muss, da man es ja einsammeln darf. Und das auch noch unter massiven Zeitdruck, da die Dinger sehr schnell sich auflösen. Es ist nicht gerade mein Spielstil, mitten in einen Pulk zu fliegen und dabei draufzugehen. Ich spiele da eher sicher, was das Spiel mir nicht erlaubt. Schließlich will der Adventure Modus zum weiterkommen bestimmte Punktevorgaben erfüllt haben.

Insgesamt ist es ein nettes Spiel für zwischendurch, das man in einem Sale, Schlussverkauf, andere Anbieter oder sonstwie sich günstig holen kann. Der Vollpreis ist meiner Meinung nach, auch in Anbetracht des Alters, nicht gerechtfertig. So ein fünfer ist okay, wenn man solche Arcade-Spiele mag.

32236947.review:
This now classic arcade made history as being one of the first twin-stick shooters that employed 3D arenas in an interesting manner - this was an important addition to the shmup genre, which really blew me away as a developer working in the same genre. But this also brought a problem: the gameplay was made harder by the 3D rotating camera. 
 
It impacts overall visibility and the clarity of collision between the player and the enemies. Also, the game is often late with its warnings to the player related to the incoming appearance of enemies.
 
This makes the player die occasionally not because of their own error but due to visual glitches. 
 
I personally didn't like the upgrades because I found it unclear in what ways are they affecting the gameplay and they didn’t really help me achieve higher scores. 
Other noteworthy features include 12 battle modes including Paciﬁsm, King, Claustrophobia and 4 all-new modes, but also the local co-op.
 
Overall this is an interesting addition to Geometry Wars franchise, but Geometry Wars 2 still sits on the throne. If you are a GW fan, I would recommend this game because it shines in all other aspects. 

If you are looking for other interesting shooter games, I would like to invite you to check our community group on Steam:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/593680

29833080.review:
This is a deceptively simple and very well-made shooter with a nice amount of game modes and variety. If you play on your own, there's some fun stuff to keep you occupied for a bit  - you can try out the different modes, beat your high score, race the clock to get enough points, go through the different challenges, etc. *However*, I don't think that there's enough single-player content to justify the asking price. If you don't have any folks to play with, this isn't worth the money. You can get it on sale or in a bundle, but full price is way too much. Even if you do have some pals to play with, you should still know that the online options really begin and end with competitive leaderboards. There's no online co-operative multiplayer, which is rather surprising and a real shame.

That being said, why am I still recommending this game? If the single player content is solid but lacking for the price, and there's no online co-op, what's to recommend? Let me tell you where this game really shines: local co-op is a blast. It's so fun to zoom around the maps, blasting all these psychedelic shapes, as your friends zip around next to you. It's hilarious to swoop in and steal their green bits or to snatch a power-up right out from under somebody's nose. There are enough game modes with enough variety so that your group will have plenty to move on to when they want to switch things up. The game is a really great way to start off a night of gaming with your group of friends.

So, this is a recommendation that comes with a caveat. If you've got a regular gaming group that plays co-op games around your PC, this game is practically a must-buy. It's still a little expensive for what it is, but it's tons of fun and your gaming buddies will love it. If you don't have a local gaming group, though, Geometry Wars 3 is much less exciting. The single-player content is definitely nice (and addictive at times), but it's not enough for you to shell out the full price, and remember that there's no online co-op feature. It comes down to how and why you like to play...it's all going to depend on what genre of games your gaming group likes, whether or not you have a regular gaming group, etc. If you and your friends like arcade-style shooters, there's no question, go for it!

28432218.review:
[h1]Geometry Wars 3 is too much of a good thing, but a good thing nonetheless[/h1]

Geometry Wars 2 (2008) was never a game that demanded a sequel. From the series’ birth as an Easter Egg in Project Gotham Racing 2 (2003) to finding its home on the early Xbox Live Arcade, Bizarre Creations’ Geometry Wars: Retro Evolved (2005) made few drastic changes but by its second numbered iteration had refined its twin-stick, neon arcade-shooter score-chase into a neo-retro diamond. Aside from perhaps Pac-Man Championship Edition DX (2010) (which borrowed indiscriminately from Geometry Wars aesthetics and leaderboard systems) no game has greater exemplified the arcade game rebirth of the last decade as greatly as Geometry Wars 2 (2008).

With Geometry Wars 2 Bizarre Creations had achieved near perfection and it is difficult to imagine how they would begin to follow up such a monumental release. But six years later what remains of the studio, now reformed as Lucid Games, attempted to do just that with the release of Geometry Wars 3: Dimensions Evolved (2014), a direct sequel that pulls ideas from both Geometry Wars 2 and the royally overlooked Wii spinoff Geometry Wars: Galaxies (2007), as well as liberal inspiration from the adjacent Super Stardust series.

The first question with a sequel like Dimensions Evolved is not “what’s changed” but “did they ruin it?” Though the return of one of XBLA’s biggest hits is more than welcome, it is hard not to see the surprise release as potentially suspect after a six-year gap and developer shuffle. The answer to that question, however, turns out to be far more difficult to answer than expected.

At first glance, Dimensions Evolved is still indisputably Geometry Wars. Bright geometric shapes zoom around spitting off particle effects as they attempt to collide with your ship, a reckless spacecraft zipping through levels shooting at anything within reach. Geometry Wars has always expertly balanced visual chaos with a focused design similar to the best bullet-hell shooters, and Dimensions Evolved hasn’t gotten sloppy in the downtime between releases. Few shooters of any variety (or hell, games in general) could claim to match the sort of sensory experience that has personified Geometry Wars’ since its inception, the act of shooting a glowing quadrilateral ranking with the likes of bopping a Goomba on the head or eating a Pac-Man ghost in regards to pitch perfect video game moments.

Like each sequel and spinoff before it, Dimensions Evolved seeks to expand upon Geometry Wars’ foundation while preserving prior games’ additions. As its title somewhat subtly implies, Dimensions Evolved sees the series expanding from its flat origins into full 3D (one can only imagine how overwhelming the game would be when viewed through a pair of anaglyph glasses) placing it far closer to Super Stardust HD (2007) than Asteroids (1979). Compared to past games Dimensions Evolved is almost blinding, the presentation a visually arresting assault of colors and explosions. But for all its technical prowess, Dimensions Evolved’s irreconcilable oversight is allowing its graphics to infringe upon its gameplay.

Geometry Wars has kept the same visual style for all of its releases, but aside from being characteristic of the series the stripped-down presentation also served a practical purpose of keeping the frantic action readable. It was never a challenge to understand what was happening or where enemies were coming from in Geometry Wars 2, but in its third iteration, this key design philosophy has been forgotten in favor of visually interesting but functionally impractical levels which the game’s rudimentary camera is incapable of compensating for. Levels range from simple spheres to peanut-shaped to curved planes and levels which move and evolve as you play through them. There is undeniably more going on in any given level of Dimensions Evolved, but very little of it feels as if it is adding something necessary.

The tone of every addition to Dimensions Evolved is a blunt “more.” More levels, more game types, more enemies, more stuff. It’s a predictable, if unexciting approach to a sequel, but what is so unfortunate is that additions that would have fundamentally benefited the series – such as auto-recorded replays ala-Pix the Cat (2014) or cross-platform leaderboards – are completely absent. What is present is an embarrassment of riches, different elements tacked on like a gaudy painting by an artist that doesn’t know when to quit.

Perhaps most remarkably frustrating is Dimensions Evolved’s recycling of Galaxies’ drone feature, effectively different power-ups which can be equipped and upgraded to give you extra fire power, collect multipliers, or defend your ship from enemies. These drones provide Dimensions Evolved with its one source of player augmentation, which in most games would be a welcome source of variety but in a game so heavily focused on score chasing upsets the playing field and renders most scores irrelevant. Geometry Wars works so well as an arcade game because it grasps that leaderboards are most compelling when they are tightly focused. Dimensions Evolved introduces so many variables between levels and drone loadouts that attempting to gain the top spot on its hundred or so leaderboards feels like a completely hopeless and pointless pursuit.

Lucid Games seems to have realized this on some level, as alongside Dimensions Evolved’s additions, a near 1-1 replica of Geometry Wars 2 has also been included as a “classic” mode. Unfortunately, the same visual problems that plague the rest of the game persist here, rendering standbys like “deadline” and “waves” mechanically identical but distinctly less playable than in past games. These classic stages are undeniably (and perhaps unsurprisingly) the most tuned to score chasing, and in turn the portion of the game most destined to replace Geometry Wars 2’s brutal quest for leaderboard dominance, but it is disappointing that even when it adheres so closely to its predecessors Dimensions Evolved can’t quite measure up.

It is important to emphasize that despite all its missteps, there is still nothing quite like Geometry Wars and even a lesser version is still among the best arcade games in recent memory. Dimensions Evolved’s biggest strength is serving as a reminder of what an amazing series Geometry Wars has always been, and providing a reason for people who long ago boxed up their 360 to jump back in and reclaim their spot on the leaderboard. Whether that means acclimating to Dimensions Evolved’s questionable changes or returning to Geometry Wars 2 or Galaxies, the result is a net win.

[b]You can find more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2016/12/17/geometry-wars-3-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

28076217.review:
I started playing this series with Geometry Wars Retro Evolved 2 on the Xbox 360. The visuals, gameplay and leaderboard score-chasing drew me in and made it a game that I could play for just a few rounds or hours at a time.

I can firmly say that this game takes all of what made the previous game great and makes it that much better. The added complexity that the 3-Dimensional environments present is a welcome addition to the series in my mind. The game also allows you to play the diffferent game modes on "Classic" stages, which are flat areas reminescent of the previous games in the series. In this way the game caters to both players who want something knew and those who are looking for the original experience but with new graphics and gameplay.

The flashy visuals are just as great as the previous games and really bring out the aracade feel of the game. Leaderboards are just as present as well and I'm glad they're still there, even though I don't think I'll ever come close to topping them. To my knowledge, the game retains all (or most of) the classic game modes while offering some new twists in the linear progresion path of the "Campaign" mode.

All in all, I would recommend this game to series veterans and newcomers alike. It manages to cater to both audiences without butchering what made the series great or adding too much to dilute the formula. This is an arcade experience that you can pick up and play for short bursts or for hours on end.

Overall this game is as fun/addicting as the previous ones, so if you liked those, you'll like this. I first wasn't sure about the 3D aspect, but it's quite a nice twist, and it does include all the old modes (minus sequence) from the other games, should you decide you don't actually like the 3D.

One thing they seem to always do is blow the previous games out of the water in terms of content, and this definitely has a lot. You'll find half a million different game modes when playing through the adventure, each with their own enemy types too. I did however find myself not replaying the missions, since you get unlocks later on that make the game easier. I can see why they did it, but it felt wrong having to leave the mission sitting there with a low score.

The visuals are great, and if you've played any of the previous games you'll know what you're in for. The one thing that annoys me a little is that the wormholes looked so cool in GM2, and on here they're just a bit boring. Other than that though, I can't think of any other bad points, definitely worth a tenner.

27472712.review: Unglaublich Geiles Game! Hier wurde die Grundidee bis zum absoluten optimum ausgereizt. Die alten Teile waren schon cool weil man verdammt viel Geschicklichkeit, Schnelligkeit und Konzentration brauchte. Der dritte Teil übertreibt es aber vollkommen.  Hier kommt jeder SuperNinja irgendwann an seine Grenzen. Die Online-Bestenliste funktioniert wunderbar und motiviert einen dabei ungemein. Es macht riesen Spaß in der Rangliste aufzusteigen. Und die Art und Weise wie die Gegner erscheinen und sich verhalten ist wirklich verdammt clever gemacht. Hier hat jemand unendlich viel Mühe hineingesteckt um jedes einzelne Level so spannend wie möglich zu machen. Man wird mit jedem Versuch besser und man merkt dass es immer noch ein bisschen besser geht. Bei den meisten Spielen dieser Art geben viele bestimmt schnell auf und stempeln es als unmöglich ab. Nicht so bei Geometry Wars 3: Dimension Evolved! Man erkennt seine Fehler und lernt immer wieder was dazu. Jede Art von Gegner und Gegnerformation bietet eine funktionierende Gegenmaßnahme. Man muss kein Übermensch sein um die Levels zu schaffen aber es braucht doch eine ordentliche Portion an skills. Definitiv ein Spiel für Menschen die Herausforderungen lieben. Nichts für Bettnässer, Weicheier, Nörgelnasen oder was auch immer. Hier erwartet euch ein Kampf der so manchen die letzten Nerven kosten kann. Menschen mit nicht so schwachen Nerven werden aber nur noch widerstandsfähiger anstatt Nerven zu verlieren. Außerdem kann es nie schaden seine Reaktionszeiten zu trainieren - könnte sogar Leben retten. Lahme Reaktionen sind einfach gefährlich in dieser Hektischen Welt. Also - spielt das Spiel und ihr lebt länger :)

Rating 9.5/10
Overview: Twin Stick shooter  

The Good:

+ Simple yet colorful graphics

+ This game features an insane amount of game modes. 

+ Variety of different levels, some levels take place on a flat surface, while others have you moving around a three-dimensional object. Some levels feature barriers, warp points, moving obstacles etc. 

+ Adventure mode allows you to equip different drones and powers to help you. Collecting gems allows you to upgrade them. 

+ Addicting gameplay

+ Game has the “just one more time” feeling to it. 

The Average: 

Not so much a fault of the game but sometimes the game can become too chaotic and it becomes almost impossible to see where the enemies are. 

I would have liked to see more graphical options and settings

Multiplayer is dead

Conclusion:

This is one of the best twin stick shooters on Steam. There is no shortage of ideas in this game and its just so fun to try out different combinations of drones and special abilities and to try and get top score.

Serious review: Must have for any arcade-fan that loves chasing high scores.

25483009.review:
Geometry Wars is a testament to quality game-design. It's a twin-stick shooter where the only goal is to shoot shapes, and yet it's exceedingly entertaining. Why shapes anyway? Besides the fact that this is the Geometry Wars series, I believe the importance of using shapes can't be understated. Speaking in terms of twin-stick shooters: shapes are simple, easy on the eyes, and players are immediately able to recognize the behavioral differences between them.

Why would "Zombie Wars" not work? Zombies, despite their lack of functioning grey matter, are really complicated. They're walking moaning hunks of undying flesh. Let's say you want to have a zombie with a gun in your twin-stick shooter. How will the player know the zombie has a gun? In the middle of chaos, nobody is going to notice the few pixels or couple polygons that's supposed to represent a gun. So here's an idea: Let's give the gun-toting zombies police-hats. Since everything is seen from an overhead perspective, the blue octagon-shape clearly indicates that these zombies have guns. Those fire-breathing zombies? Give them red oval-shaped fireman hats. 

And just like that, we're right back where we started. In the time it takes to read that inane scenario, every single enemy shape & color in Geometry Wars can be memorized. The basis of a great arcade game is in presenting everything that is necessary to the player's survival, within seconds of pressing the start button. The sequels to Geometry Wars expand upon its simple concept, but never to the point where they endanger what makes it work. The adventure mode in Geometry Wars 3 is liable to be where most players begin. Each stage has a specific goal, and there's usually a factor to consider such as contracting walls, a boss, or a complete lack of weapons. However, none of these stages ever go as far as to contradict how the game is meant to be played. You survive by dodging shapes and improve your score-multiplier by collecting geoms.

Alongside its classic 2D stages, Dimensions Evolved adds numerous 3D stages. At times these can be interesting, such as the "rainbow" stages that require players to destroy painters. The painters can spawn on the other side of the field, or tucked away into corners just out of sight. However, there are those rare moments where the perspective can be distracting. It's like the designers are running dangerously close to visually overloading the game. Either that, or I'm just prone to looking for excuses when I fail.

This edition also adds load-outs such as drones and mines because... eh. I don't dislike their inclusion, but it's really not something that feels necessary. In these games, strategies are usually come up with "on the fly". As the in-game situation constantly changes, the gears in your head are spinning, and the intent is to always stay one step ahead. Load-outs add pre-game strategizing, so you might find yourself saying "I bet if I used the sweep drone, I would have beat my friend's hi-score." Everything about Geometry Wars is strong enough to stand on its own, it doesn't need load-outs. On the bright side, if you lack the "mad skillz" to succeed, then the load-outs are only a band-aid. Besides, it's not like everyone on the leaderboards isn't using them either.

Also, there is a degree of cleverness to the drones that I have to applaud. The aforementioned sweep drone flies in a full circle around the player, but it can bounce off of walls. During one stage, I discovered this quirk, and then used it to get out of tight-spots. 

Geometry Wars 3 features a wealth of content. The adventure mode is 50 stages, and a couple of free expansions tack on even more. These aren't the "play once and forget about them" kind of stages either. Although, there are a few that can be annoying or dull. There's one stage that involves destroying giant snake-shapes. It was so easy I had to destroy myself, just so I could move on. Still, the occasional boring stage is forgivable. There are also a handful of classic modes, which are 3D & load-out free for the purists. Everything you play has a leaderboard attached to it, with solid friend support to boot. There's also a co-op mode. I assume it's nice, but I'll probably never play it. 

Thanks to a recent humble bundle, this game has likely recieved a large influx of new owners. My advice is to give this game an immediate look. As a Geometry Wars fan, I'll say that this entry nails everything that it needs to. Some of the new ideas don't click perfectly, but at least I know where they were going with them. All too often, sequels make the mistake of adding something completely different, and it takes away from the core game. Even in the fully 3D stages, Dimensions Evolved's core is still very apparent and fantastic.

25370619.review:
Pros
- Easy uptake on initial controls (it's just a twin-stick shooter!) with some surprising depth and memorability on level strategies and boss battles
- Classic "feel" with enough modern refinements to feed an addictive approach to gameplay
- Multiplayer/co-op options that the franchise deserves
- Retro presentation holds up and is as awesome to watch as it is to play
- You can throw away the previous franchise games - all of the previous games are basically here in the other modes

Cons
- Most ally drone modes and Super States (temporary upgrades) have a disappointingly conservative design
- Drone "Supers" are infrequently used and often underwhelming effects that don't influence overall gameplay or strategy until they are fully upgraded
- The drones feel like a flat-out missed opportunity to provide a deeper, more frenetic experience
- Punishing deaths and linear progression in Adventure modes mean you can get stuck on a level for quite some time

Play this
- ... if you love any sort of twin-stick shooter
- ... if you love "quickies" that you can turn into hour-long sessions
- ... if you have always wanted to but never attended a rave or EDC event and want a relatively safe substitute complete with psychadelic colors, pyrotechnic explosions, flashing lights, an electronic music soundtrack and an addiction experience

Avoid this
- ... if you are prone to sensory overload
- ... if you get bothered by awkward menu flows like a "Quick Retry" option usurped by an even quicker "[X] RESTART" option
- ... if you want anything resembling an actual narrative structure in something called "Adventure mode"

25300451.review:
看到很多人反映这个游戏的入门难度比较高，加上这个周末这款游戏又一次打折，于是自己写了一篇指南，希望能够对初次接触这款游戏的玩家有所帮助。
【注：本指南为科普性质，介绍的为Adventure模式下的游戏内容，对技术讲解并不多（后续根据需要补充），适用于尚未购买这款游戏的玩家和初次接触这款游戏的玩家】

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=756507507]http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=756507507[/url]

===============================================

<2016/10/6 更新>
在指南发布之后，我自己和同学在本地完成了全部10个合作关卡并达成了全3星，而Adventure的50个关卡在今天也成功达成了150星全3星的成就。这段时间里一直在猛攻Adventure里剩余关卡的3星，确实有些消磨耐心，不过最后掌握了节奏也慢慢都打过了。如果有对Adventure的50个关卡打法有疑问，可以来咨询我~

补充一下关于联机和合作关卡的一些事情：
①【注意！】联机模式不等于合作模式。联机模式为多人同屏的比分竞赛，而合作模式的10个关卡只能在本地完成，并不支持联机！
②合作模式可最多支持4人同时玩，而且可以跨操作模式，比如我和同学玩的时候我使用的是键鼠操作，同学用的手柄。
③合作模式里，所有的Drone和Super都不可用，Smartbomb有限量但在一定情况下会自动回复1个。
④合作模式里尽量不要死。与Adventure不同的是，如果在合作模式里死了，死掉的那一方所获得的倍乘将会全部清0，只能从1开始重新积累。

================================================

<原评测部分>
作为自己库里玩的时间最长的一款STG，我认为这款游戏从各个方面来说真的可以被称为精品。

[h1]画面[/h1]
正如商店页面上的展示画面一样，几何元素与非常简洁的UI相结合，加上绚丽的战斗特效，喜爱科幻风格的玩家会非常享受这种独特的STG体验。另外，游戏占用空间仅1G左右，对电脑配置要求很低，可以轻松达到60FPS。注意，由于游戏在全屏模式下存在低FPS的bug，所以推荐使用Borderless模式进行游戏。另外为了避免不必要的卡顿，请在游戏前将输入法关闭。

[h1]音乐[/h1]
音乐也是这款游戏的一大亮点。游戏内有多个模式，每个模式下都有其自己的bgm，电子气息十足，对于我这种电音爱好者来说是一种享受。个人最喜欢Deadline、Titan和Boss战的bgm。不过比较可惜的是我只能找到这个游戏GST的CloudMusic，暂时没法下载。

[h1]玩法[/h1]
不得不承认，这个游戏的入门难度偏高。当初我是小白的时候，前面5关打起来相当吃力，后来慢慢地，熟悉了操作之后，目前Adventure的50关一共得到了125星。操作方面有键鼠和手柄两种方式，但我认为对于这个游戏我使用键鼠比手柄更好上手。
另外游戏内的玩法也很丰富。以Adventure为例，Adventure内设有多个游戏模式，每种游戏模式有自己的特色，对应不同模式需要选择不同的Power Up搭配来帮助自己通关。另外，敌类个体的种类非常丰富，每种个体具有其特色，具体的游戏模式和敌类个体介绍可以参阅我发布的游戏指南。
游戏的节奏可以说是相当紧张刺激的，相当多的敌类个体具有趋向性，生成后都会直接向飞行器的方向高速运动，你几乎没有任何时间停下来休息。根据我自己的游戏体验，游戏过程中截图真的是很难，稍微不留神就翘辫子了。
另外这个游戏也支持联机玩法，不过我还没体验过，暂不评价。

[h1]总评[/h1]
9.7/10
强烈推荐STG爱好者、科幻风爱好者入手这款游戏。
[spoiler]才不是强烈推荐你们体验当抖M的感觉2333[/spoiler]

Il giocatore controlla una navetta che si muove in due dimensioni sopra una figura che può essere piana o tridimensionale, cercando di distruggere quanti più nemici possibile e aumentare il moltiplicatore del punteggio raccogliendo dei piccoli rombi verdi, chiamati Geom all'interno del gioco. 25013806.review:
As a standalone twin-stick shooter it's great. As a sequel to Geometry Wars 2 it's not. Allow me to explain...

On an aesthetic level Geometry Wars 3 looks the business and demands to be witnessed on an absurdly large telly. Top marks for presentation although there's an irritating labyrinth of menus in order to select a specific level.

The music is blandly average and doesn't really ramp up with the intensity of the levels. There's nothing that gets the blood pumping like, say, this:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=09Uq0pWcg3Q

There's a few other niggles that will only be apparent if you've played the previous games. Spawn time seems a little 'off': I lost count of the amount of times that I'd been killed by an enemy with no conceivable warning. In the previous games there would usually be an audio cue to signal an incoming enemy but there's no such luck here. 
Some of the three dimensional level shapes, while looking incredible, do impede the fast-paced nature of gameplay; for example, not seeing an enemy hiding on the edge of a cube.

The one addition that really rankles me, though, is loadouts. In previous games the joy would be in simply bettering your own score. Here, you're constantly wondering what combination of perks will enable you to absolutely merk that particular level. It seems each level has been designed to have one 'correct' way to play. Even more infuriatingly, certain modes, levels and perks are hidden behind a fairly arbitary unlock system. Just give me access to everything from the start! 

I realise this is a fairly negative review but, in spite of the missteps, the DNA of Geometry Wars is unstoppable and, as such, Geometry Wars 3 is still a worthwhile purchase in spite of the caveats mentioned.

Geometry Wars 3 is easily the best in the series and thats saying something since the other 2 games were amazing. The extra dimension that they add to this game really spices it up, instead of just fighting on a flat surface like the previous games, you will also be fighting on Cubes, spheres, peanuts and much more. All the original classic modes return such as pacifism, but alos others are introduced as well. Their is a story mode with a wide variety of diferent challenges as well as boss fights that are quite challenging if not done properly. Their is an Ultimate and a hardcore mode for hardocre veterans of the games. Their is a leaderboard that keep track of your rank against friends as well as your position on the global leaderboards. The controls feel tight and movement is just as smooth as ever, which you would expect from a Geometry Wars game. Their is a COOP mode as well so you can play with a buddy. The soundtrack is amazing just like the previous 2 games. Easily one of the best arcade games on the market, I own it on 3 different platforms(Vita, Xbone, PC) and can be very competitive between friends. Highly recommended!

I can't believe I've never left a review of this game. 

I'll keep it simple and short, if you liked the Sequence mode of GW2, you'll LOVE the 'story modes' in GW3. Most of the maps are 3D, the patterns are repetitive for the most part, the bosses are challenging and they spruced it up with different styles of game play that leaves you on your toes. There is some multiplayer modes, but I haven't had a chance to utilize them. 

Some people complain that there isn't enough forewarning when it comes to the spawning of new shapes and that some of the maps may be [i]too[/i] difficult. A friend bought it for me, but I've also gifted it to my friends. It goes on sale pretty frequently for at least 50% off. Do yourself a favor and GRAB IT.  You've already waited too long.

23116880.review:
A long time ago, I bought Geometry Wars Galaxies for the Nintendo DS. I absolutely loved it. It did everything right, and let me tell you using a stylus to shoot did not make things easy, especially for a lefty.

Years later, I bought this game (shortly after its release if I remember correctly). It was a decent price and I knew the graphics would have my eyes sparkling and my mouth puking rainbows. And I was right. Visually, this game is absolutely stunning. The many game modes and three-dimensional levels make it a huge step forward from Galaxies. Plus now my drone has awesome special attacks (called supers), and Super States give me a chance at getting a huge edge, if only very briefly.

So why can't I recommend this game?
It's a lot of things, but it mostly boils down to the fact that in this game, death means that you have to restart the level, either because (depending on the game mode) you only have a single life, or because while you have infinite lives, you have an extremely short time limit. Combine these issues with the following:
- Enemy spawn animations are very brief and easy to miss, especially when you're focusing not directly on your ship where they're spawning, but on the enemies you're currently shooting at.
- A lot of the levels, due their 3-D design, give you almost no visibility around you.
- There are many enemies whose speed makes them hard enough to dodge even when you can see them coming a mile away.

It doesn't help that you need those impossible-to-earn stars to actually progress through the game's single-player adventure mode.

In short, while the action is fast-paced and gorgeous, I can't recommend a game that has you spending hours on end just to make next to no progress. It would have been nice to include a few levels that worked like Galaxies, where you start with three lives, one bomb, one super, and can earn more of each by scoring enough points. The complete removal of this game mode (and mentality) has left me frustrated, and it's the type of game that ensures I'd get very, very fat if I had a swear jar (because I'd spend all that money on candy and ice cream).

22647512.review:
I like Geometry Wars. It took the gameplay of Robotron and expanded it, while at the same time simplifying it.
The action was frentic. The enemies, while simple in their AI, had a tendency to gang up on you and cause your inevitable demise. And games usually lasted short time enough that you could always just restart to have one more go at the high score.
Geometry Wars: Galaxies for the Wii expanded upon this by adding different shaped levels, medals to set you some goals and some mutators like certain types of waves in the levels to give you some variety over the classic Retro Evolved. 

I hear Geometry Wars 2 did rather well as well, adding game concepts like checkpoints or bubbles in which you need to stay in order to shoot. Expanding on the original to add some flavour.

And now there's Geometry Wars 3. The main draw over GW2 seems to be the 3D angle, it's right there in the title. The graphics look a lot more futuristic and flashy. Gone are those silly vectorlike wireframes. Hello flat shaded 3D backgrounds, blurry lighting effects. The works.

Sadly this is what really soured the experience for me. The art looks really good, especially in motion. But instead of the lines coming together to form newly spawned enemies, you just get a faint intensifying glow before the enemy is there. Instead of having a good view of the playfield, suddenly you're limited in how far you can see, especially on the cubes and spheres where enemies will seemingly out of the blue turn a corner and ram into you, because the camera wasn't showing you that angle.

At its heart, this game is very much an extension on Geometry Wars. With game modes from GW2, and slicker graphics. But for me it just turned to frustration to once again get spawnkilled by a powerup because I missed the slight glow. Or to get run into by an enemy coming around the corner I was moving towards. The third dimension, for as awesome as it seems, almost completely ruins the game for me. 

80% of the deaths I died felt like a graphical gotcha. I died not because I lost track of where the enemies were, not because I stupidly wandered into something because i was looking at where I was, or because the enemies had surrounded me. I died because of something I didn't have a chance to see before it was too late. Or because I missed a bit of coloured light in the middle of multicoloured explosions.

It's a pity really. I really wanted to like this game, and on the flat levels this game is almost as much fun as the old incarnations of the game. But as it is I can't recommend getting GW3. Go play the old ones instead, they're hard enough without falling back on optical trickery to kill you.

说下个人经验。

跟班小弟选择：全程用收集宝石的，BOSS除外。

超级武器（Q）：每个都很强，看个人喜欢，跟踪蛋前期首选。

BOSS战：有好几个阶段，每过一个阶段，BOSS的皮会少一层。
技巧：优先选第一个跟班小弟，感觉这货的子弹打BOSS和玩家的伤害一样，非常快。只要关注好自己附近！！！不用追求分数，BOSS自身的分数就够进去下一关。

22296044.review:
Geometry Wars 3 is possibly the gold standard (or at least silver standard) for twinstick shooters on Steam, polished to a sheen and packed to the gills with content.  The bulk of the game consists of "Adventure" mode, a linear progression through 50 maps.  Lucid Games did an admirable job injecting an impressive amount of variety into each of the levels.  The result is that you usually won't feel like you're trying to achieve the same objective over and over again (for 50 maps).  There are a few duds in the mix--I've never been a fan of the missions where you see how long you can prevent enemies from completely "painting" the arena--but the game makes up for it with a lot of missions that are genunely fun to replay.

Reaching certain goals and milestones unlocks upgrades for your ship (like buddy drones and super weapons) while obtaining higher scores grants you a sort of currency that can be used to improve these upgrades.  While you'll ultimately have more points to spend than things to invest them in, you can only take one of each type on a given mission with you, so you need to think about the level you're going in to and what will benefit you most.  Maybe a defensive buddy is important for a 1-life survive-as-long-as-you-can mission, but a gem (point) collector drone is better for a timed mission.  Similarly, certain super weapons are better on certain maps than others.  The ability to customize your loadout helps add some depth to the game.  

In addition to "Adventure" mode are three other main modes:  "Ultimate" mode, which plays like a crazier, 40-level version of "Adventure" mode; "Hardcore" mode, which is primarily levels from "Adventure" and "Ultimate" modes, minus the ability to use drones/super weapons, and "Classic" mode, which is simply the ability to choose from the 6 primary mission types featured in previous Geometry Wars installments.  

As the game is all about stars, points, and high-scores, it can really create a "one more time" itch for people who like seeing how high they can get on the leaderboards.  The game itself provides a reasonable challenge--I wouldn't qualify it as an especially difficult twinstick shooter by any stretch--but for those who are looking to score 3-stars (or beat friends/global scores) the game can put up enough of a fight that you probably won't sleepwalk through levels.  

Package it all up in a coherent lo-fi arcade art-style and you've got a solid twinstick-shooter timesink that likely offers more content than the average person will be able to tackle.  I probably wouldn't recommend taking it on without a gamepad of some sort, though.

20261892.review:
[b]THIS REVIEW IS FOR PLAYERS WITHOUT CONTROLLERS[/b]

If you are going to play it with a mouse and keyboard, I suggest you don't waste your money on it.

[h1]What Expected:[/h1]
Here are the enemies! Let me shoot ya in the face!

[h1]Truth:[/h1]
Where am I?
Where are those geoms?
Where are the enemies?
Where is my cursor?
I think I need a controller.

[h1]Explanation:[/h1]
Your ship shoots towards the position of your cursor. So for accurate aiming, [b]you need to know where your cursor is[/b]. Somebody might argue that you can just keep shooting and adjust the angle. The problem is, since the distance between your ship and your cursor isn't fixed (the cursor can be anywhere on the screen), most of the time the adjustment is super inaccurate if you do not keep an eye on your cursor position.
 
[b]However, keeping an eye on the cursor is quite distracting in GW3.[/b] Most of the time you might focus on the enemies, especially those fast and/or small ones. Meanwhile, you should also locate the geoms, which is tiny green gems that increases your score multiplier. Geoms are dropped from enemies and will disappear after a few seconds, It is essential to catch enough geoms, otherwise you might even find it hard to get 1 star out of 3. If using a controller, it is acceptable to focus on these stuff. But if you are using the keyboard and mouse, you should also focus on the cursor, which is very distracting.

Personally, I feel frustrated while playing GW3. This does not mean I don't like playing twin-stick-shooter games. I used to play Waves and it makes me feel much better. Frankly, the graphic of GW3 is great and I really want to love it. But the experience was so bad.

Pour one out for all the good shapes we lost in these senseless geometry wars.

This game is the twin-stick shooter to beat. It is a treat of controls, visuals, audio, and difficulty. If I was forced to choose a small number of single player games to live with forever, this would be the admiral of the fleet. It's replay value is perfect. One stick moves, the other shoots. You have buttons for bombs, your basic panic button, and specials, which to me feel like sort of mitigation or back-up half-panic. In most modes killing enemies drops green pellets that you can pick up to increase your multiplier for sweet sweet points.

You are some sort of sharp edged open pentagon thing. You shoot bullets at over shapes, each of which behave in their own unique neurotic way. Many blindly move abut paying no heed to you. Some bumrush you. My favorite are the green shapes, that are skittish and will run away when shot at. There are also a number of bosses, and the boss music is incredible to be sure. I still nod my head to it and jam out. There's multiplayer as well, for some pew pew.

The aesthetic of this game is something like Tron, and there is this ague sense that this is all happening in some technological device. The music is great, and I wish there was more of it. I also wish there were more exotic geometries, as everything seems so Platonic and regular. Klein bottles? Eldritch higher dimensional planes? Anyone?

Connaissant la série que par la version Wii, j'ai été agréablement surpris par ce troisième opus. Twin sitck shooter simple, mais efficace qui ajoute une nouvelle dimension avec des aires de jeux en 3D.
Le reproche qui pourrait être fait à cette évolution vient de la perte de lisibilité de l'ensemble en sachant que l'aire de jeu n'est pas visible d'un seul coup d'œil. Cela pèse bien peu dans le feu de l'action.

Le mode aventure est riche, difficile et suffisamment varié avec ces différents modes de jeu pour éviter la lassitude inhérente à ce genre de jeu. Le jeu propose aussi d'autres modes dont un retour à ce qu'était Geometry Wars.

19108246.review:
[b]Quick Breakdown:[/b] An excellent twin stick shooter, featuring various modes of play, plenty of levels, and classic modes for the previous games.
[b]Length:[/b] 20+ hours
[b]Genre:[/b] Twin Stick Shooter
[b]Score:[/b] 8.5/10

[b]Full Review:[/b] I bought this game because I was constantly seeing a notification for one of my friends on Steam playing it, so I figured I’d see what he was logging all those hours into and give it a chance. Goddamn, am I glad I did too, because this game is fantastic.

I’ve played the 1st [i]Geometry Wars[/i] game, though not the second. This game is a huge step up from the first, and from what I can tell, a huge step up from the second as well. If you like the old games then you should love this one too. If you’re new to the series then this is the best place to start. It has the classic mode from the first game, and I think it has all the modes from the second as well. At the least, it has about a half dozen other classic game modes in addition to the main game. I won’t spend any more time on these classic modes since they aren’t the main focus of this game, but suffice it to say that they provide added entertainment to the game.

If you do get this game, I highly recommend getting an X-Box controller for Windows, as this game is unplayable with just a keyboard, or with a keyboard and mouse. For this review, when I refer to the controls I’m referring specifically to when using a controller.

The gameplay itself is very simple, you control a highly maneuverable ship that can shoot in any direction, you use one joy stick to move, and the other to shoot. One of the shoulder buttons will release a bomb that clears the screen of enemies, while the other will release a special attack depending on the drone you picked, (more on the drones later). How many times you can use a bomb or special attack depends on the level. Usually just once per stage, sometimes up to three, and sometimes none.

The meat of the gameplay is done in adventure mode, which is a series of levels featuring a variety of different modes. Each level is completed by earning enough points to get a 1 star rating. You can earn up to 3 stars for each level by further surpassing higher and higher score thresholds. (I’ll talk more about the stars later). Different levels have different maps, while some of them are flat, most of them are various 3 dimensional shapes that you can cruise across the entire surface of.

Some of the different game modes include scoring enough points under a certain time limit, in which you have infinite lives. Other modes you have only one or three lives and must reach the score before you exhaust your lives. There’s a mode where you can only attack from inside domes that spawn and disappear from the map. The game also features bosses, and a handful of other game modes to play.

Earning points in a level is as simple as destroying your enemies, which consist of different geometric shapes that each behave in a different manner. Each time you kill an enemy they drop green gems, known as geoms, that increase your score multiplier. You pick up the geoms simply by piloting near them.

When you pick a level you can also choose your loadout, which consists of a drone and a drone super. The first affects the ship you pilot, such as increasing your attack spread, or having a drone that automatically seeks and collects geoms for you. The super gives you another attack to use in the level, such as dropping a turret that shoots for a short period of time, or a black hole that sucks in all the enemies for a short while. When you complete a boss level you unlock a new drone super, though you must purchase it first. You purchase it with the stars you earn by completing levels, so earning more stars than needed per level has more benefit than just bragging rights. You can purchase upgrades for both drones and the drone supers with geoms. Each time you finish a level, regardless of if you complete it successfully or not, all the geoms you collected  are added to the funds you can spend towards upgrades. Upgrading your drones and supers will make the game a bit easier, though you’ll still need to figure out the best combination of drone and super for a level.

All that is well and good for the game, and certainly worth the price of purchase, but about 4 months after the game was released it received a massive update. It’s the sort of update that was loaded with enough quality content that I wouldn’t mind throwing a few bucks at it for DLC, but the developer’s instead went the commendable route of including it as a free update. If you already owned the game, you got all the new content for free. If you purchase the game today, then you’ll get all the new content with it.

This new content featured over 40 new levels, a new drone, a new super, new game modes, and new enemies. The new levels are split between two new game modes. One is essentially a hard mode for adventure, featuring new levels (some of which feature new game modes themselves). The other is a hardcore mode, which serves as another adventure mode, but this time you cannot use drones or supers. It’s essentially an adventure mode, but with just the abilities of the old games. (You could view it as a “classic” adventure mode).

The new update also slightly tweaked the original adventure mode. Originally, when you played through the game you had to earn a certain number of stars before you could fight a boss. For example, the first boss was the 10th level, and I think it required 15 stars; meaning that you had to earn higher than just 1 star on the 9 levels before it. The update required this star requirement. The star requirement was an unnecessary obstacle that sometimes lead to replying levels more than was enjoyable, just to earn enough stars to advance further. That’s the only tweak to the base of the game that I’m aware of, and I’m glad that it was one that fixed one of the game’s flaws.

I sunk about 20 hours into the game to complete all the base content and the added levels of the update. The game can be completed faster than that given the removal of the star requirement, meaning one will only replay levels when they actually want to. I also spent a lot of time trying to get 3 stars on as many levels as possible just because of how much fun it was. So while I’m not sure exactly how long would be needed to finish the game (I’d guess around 12-15, but I could be off), I was able to thoroughly enjoy it for over 20 hours.

[i]Geometry Wars 3[/i] is a fantastic twin shooter. You’ll want a controller to play it, but it’s well worth the price.

17901122.review:
The colors swirled in my mind long after the initial experience had waned. Trails of light danced across my mind's eye and faded from existence, into the dark endless void of my memories. I had been here before, in another time and place, but not quite like this.

I recall a vision of a simpler time, when stages were 2D and there was only one large box shape to choose from. Enemies would spawn from all around, different colors and shapes each with their own personalities and behaviors. Yes, those were simpler times. But simpler times only give way to more advanced versions of themselves in the future, and the future is now!

I began my journey back into the war of shapes and vertices, raging since the dawn of xbox360. My ship handled comfortably and was just as I had remembered... moving, shooting, and high energy disintegration bombs. But what's this? New and improved technologies have given me advanced weapons of war, multiple companion drones to choose from, each with their own deadly abilities. On top of that I had been given a second special attack slot, and an arsenal of fantastic devices to choose from.

I jumped into the fray, determined to give these multifaceted miscreants a reminder of who I was. A veteran of the old war, bringing my enemy not only memories of defeat and despair, but the chance to experience these things all over again. At first it was a breeze, wave after wave of neon polygons fell to my superior prowess.

A pattern of dots appeared on the map, shiny and chrome, glistening in the psychedelic hues that enveloped the world around me. Blaster fire proved an effective solution as usual, and I was rewarded with upgraded firepower. Now golden bolts of justice were being dispensed in all directions, the map was nearly mine. Retaliations were to be expected, and sure enough they appeared on the horizon. Glowing blue homing cubes, followed by more evasive green tesseracts converged from my starboard side. But as they sought to conquer my life I had found in me greater resolve to live, and my supercharged blasters had a wide enough spray to lay waste to them all. Are they even trying? Nothing can stop me now, their defeat is to me but a simple game.

Suddenly I was aware that my vigilance had failed me, I was not in a game, I was in a battle for survival, and the slightest lapse of attention would be met with fatal repercussions. A tear in space-time opened in a nearby corner of the map. Out from that inter-dimensional orifice poured dozens of cancerous glowing peenises. Their neon blue heads throbbing and probing their environment for supple spacecraft to penetrate, their long red shafts, engorged with hatred and blood-lust trailing behind them. The others had all been attacking from one direction and lulled me into a false sense of confidence. I snapped back to reality only to click my smartbomb trigger and hear the sound many valiant souls before me had heard, the sound of doom, of the inevitable and immediate return to the void, ammunition depleted.

Geometry Wars 3: Dimentions Evolved is possibly one of the best arcade style games to ever be produced.

I first played Geometry Wars on my Nintendo Wii a while back in Geometry Wars Galaxies- only to be immediately hooked onto the simple gameplay design and incredibly hard- yet, addictive gameplay- so naturally I went and looked for a more modern version of the game on my PC, and to be honest- even from the moment I set eyes upon this game- I knew I would love it.

I waited a very long time to get a good deal on it- this game rarely ever goes on sale for lower then 8 dollars. Fortunately I was able to get a key from GameStop PC for about $3.75. After playing the game, I almost feel like I robbed the game developers blind at that price.

Geometry Wars 3 is worth every penny of it's $15 pricetag, featuring over 10 varietions on the game modes of Geomtery Wars, each providing very different, very unique twists on the retro inspired Twin Stick shooter style of gameplay- and so many ways to experience each game mode through the addition of over 50 unique levels- the game really hits all the right notes for me.

Truthfully, this is another game where I simply love it so much- I can't help but think there's something hard-wired into my brain to like it. There must be some kind of bias here- but honstly- if looking at even a screenshot peaks your interest, pick this up. Don't wait on it either. It's an incredible game.

This is by far one of the best games I own.
Geometry Wars 3 starts off slow enough for anyone to pick it up and try it out,  yet it quickly increases in challenge, making the whole experience very intense.
Even though the game rates player scores on a 1-3 star system, knowing that I could get to the next rank up if I did THAT much better, or that I could beat my friend's highscore if I lasted THAT much longer really pulled me in and got me going in this game.
There is so much finesse to Geometry Wars since enemies come at you from all directions, and one false move can ruin a run and keep you off the high score boards. This game seems to have no skill ceiling, yet it manages to test and torment players in a variety of manners.
This title includes a 50 stag-long adventure mode, similar 15 and 20 stage-long hardcore and ultimate modes, and several challenge stages that act as their own independent modes. There is also local and online competitive and co-operative multiplayer, yet I haven't ever tried to play this. Basically there's a ton of content in this game for $15.
Geometry Wars 3 is a fun and very difficult title that I reccomend to anyone looking to challenge themselves

16803337.review:
A mon sens, de loin le meilleur Geometry Wars de la série. Véritable chef d'oeuvre dans le genre Shoot them up dans un espace délimité. Geometry Wars c'est avant tout du challenge, du scoring et des musiques électroniques qui déchirent ! Ne cherchez pas de scénario, de personnages charismatiques à incarner et de morale en fin d'histoire. Non. ARCADE ONLY IS THE RULE !
On ne change pas une recette qui gagne, on retrouve les modes et les ennemis classiques depuis le premier volet "Retro Evolved" sorti en 2005 mais également de nombreuses nouveautés dont un mode coopération en ligne (pas trop fréquenté par la communauté, hélas). Le principal apport de cet opus est, comme son nom l'indique, des niveaux en trois dimensions. La surface plane n'a pas disparu pour autant mais le concept est maintenant suranné, il était nécessaire, pour le renouveau de la série, de proposer quelque chose de la sorte. Il faut dire que l'idée est géniale maintenant votre petit vaisseau peut arpenter la surface d'une sphère, d'un cylindre, d'un cube, d'une "peanut" géante et autres formes indescriptibles. Cela rajoute du piment dans des parties qui sont toujours ultra prenantes si vous aimez le genre et le scoring hardcore. À chaque fin de partie, votre score est évalué par rapport au classement mondiale, ça motive toujours (en tout cas pour moi ça marche). J'ai d'ailleurs obtenu sur un niveau la 33e place, je suis fier comme un bar-tabac ! Haha Donc, je disais que les surfaces en 3D sont intéressantes à jouer et apportent une vraie plus-value au gameplay car il faut désormais se méfier des ennemis hors-champs qui vous tombent sur le blair sans sommation ! Là est la principale difficulté. Pour être tout à fait honnête chers lecteurs, 70% de mes morts en pleine partie (et je suppose que ça doit être le cas pour les autres joueurs) proviennent d'un ou des ennemis hors-champs qui me foncent dessus ou que je percute sans avoir fait attention.
Le mode aventure, sur lequel j'ai passé pas loin de 15 heures, est super sympa. Il s'agit d'un enchaînement de 50 niveaux dans lesquels il vous faut débloquer au minimum une étoile sur trois pour passer au suivant. Je ne vous ferai pas l'affront de vous expliquer que pour avoir trois étoiles, il suffit de faire le meilleur score possible... Non, je n'oserai pas ;) D'ailleurs, vu que je suis un champion et que le monde se doit de le savoir, j'ai réussi à remporter trois étoiles sur les 50 niveaux...
Bref, trêve d'humilité, ce jeu est une tuerie pour les personnes qui apprécient les jeux d'arcades purs, qui aiment recommencer des niveaux pour battre des records, qui aiment la difficulté (pas insurmontable) dans une ambiance electro. Question graphique, c'est sobre mais réussi. J'adore le contraste entre l'espace et les figures géométriques lumineuses et colorées, ça claque ! Bref, esthétiquement Geometry Wars fait son office, on n'en demande pas plus ni moins à ce type de jeu. Je recommande² chaudement : du challenge en perspective à moindre prix messieurs, sur Steam le jeu vaut que dalle !
Allez hop, on dégaine la CB !

16739904.review: The original Geometry Wars (Retro Evolved) is one of the best twin stick shooters around and this third entry in the franchise is much better than that gold standard by improving upon it in every conceivable way. There are dozens of modes, over 50 levels, a superb concept of a 3D grid folding back upon itself to open up new ways to travers the grid and take down enemies all mixed up very well with constant rage-quit preventing variety (bored of one level? play another!). You also have power-ups in the form of drones and special pickups granting temporary enhanced shots. I found the difficulty fair if at times a bit on the hard side. The game is an excellent PC port that runs fluidly with pulsing bright, colourful and smoothly flowing graphics all punctuated by excellent music setting the tone for the frenetic gameplay. I read reports of people encountering technical issues but I never experienced any myself, most likely since the game has been patched since release. Speaking of patches, the developers released a free content pack several months after release along with a patch that many recent games would try and sell as DLC, just shows that they actually respect their players and they really deserve to be supported. If you like arcade shooters and like good value (hours upon hours worth of content here) you really should try out this game. I recommend playing this with a gamepad as twin stick shooters generally control better with a gamepad but the keyboard and mouse controls are also very well done.

16462442.review:
终于折扣了，买买买！

1代以前曾在360玩过，是个人少数几个拿手的小游戏之一，曾经和好友在家里玩的不亦乐乎。游戏节奏快，火爆刺激这些老掉牙的调调就不说了，我想安利的是：千万不能小看这个游戏，这个游戏的任何截图和视频都比不上自己玩时的真正感受。几何战争的美并非体现在3A级大作所尝试的那种与现实世界距离的无限接近之中，而恰恰是体现在它的反面。这是一个所有元素都笼罩着幻光炫彩的几何图形之中的世界，整个游戏就仿佛一部超现实主义的艺术品，它虽然抽象、简约，却又很少会让人感到单一或是重复。而这一切再配上与画面与战斗珠联璧合的电子音乐，其所带来的美妙简直让人无法形容。


具体来说这代吧。依旧是简单的几何图形和绚丽的色彩（特效）搭配到一起，却还是如同加入了催化剂一般令人沉迷。这次加入了维度的概念，令战斗场景3维化，再加上波动空间效果，各种拖尾效果，爆炸效果等等各种不算过分瞎眼的特效效果集合在一起，将游戏的画面渲染的更加迷幻。从游戏画面这个角度来说，这代的几何战争已经完美的把简洁和华丽这2个矛盾的特性完美的统一在了一起，我是暂时想不出更好的赞美语句了。


游戏的玩法与传统的“弹幕地狱”基本一样，核心操作依然是躲避+射击。但是因为3D形态的关卡地图设计，导致战场不再是一个平面，而是诸如球体或是圆柱之类的立体几何形状，玩家和敌人都要在这些立体图形的表面进行移动。这样的设计在一定程度上限制了战场视野，同时也逼迫玩家改变自己的索敌和闪避等战斗习惯。毫无疑问，这种战场设计带来了许多超越传统二轴设计游戏的新变数。操控自己的几何战机在一个圆柱体表面移动和战斗时，那种感觉更加玄妙。


游戏的关卡设计在前作是无限模式，但是这代的街机模式加入了线性关卡。说实话，真TM变态！作为一个老手居然出现了卡关！这就算了，没想到后面还有BOSS出现！这些关卡是谁设计的，我真想打死关卡设计师！

还有分数获得的设计，我其实是真不想说了……作为一款传统射击游戏，我知道天文数字的高分，也是每个玩家的终极追求之一。在几何战争中，收集敌机死亡后的绿色小碎片可以获得额外分数奖励，这些可爱的小东西虽然能够带来高分收益，但由于消失速度很快，又只会在敌人的“尸体”旁出现，想要获得高分必须经常以身犯险，穿插在敌人身边收集这些方块，让玩家自愿自觉的将游戏的目的超越了“通关”和“生存”，这与《斑鸠》的双色吸收系统有异曲同工之妙。但是每次打完关卡后，世界排行榜的分数真的令我膝盖受到了极大的暴击伤害！你们这帮变态是修炼了多少年出山的啊！

另外，在经典关卡中，还有几何战争1的无限关卡模式出现，还有波次关卡、无射击关卡等关卡模式出现，对于几何战争老玩家来说，本作的情怀其实也是满满的。


总而言之，《几何战争3：维度》核心玩法简单而清晰，又有深入研究的空间和相当丰富的重复游玩价值。这代的立体关卡更是让新鲜感持续不断的在屏幕中喷涌而出，弥补了传统二轴射击游戏关卡多样性差的短板。它本身或许还不足以复兴整个STG游戏类型，但无论你是追求自残自虐的骨灰玩家或是只想“爽”两把的弱鸡菜鸟，都能在它的世界里找到自己的乐趣。

三个字：买买买！

16401310.review:
GW3 ist ein schnelles Arcade-Ballerspiel. 

Man steuert ein Ding, das auf feindliche Formen ballern kann: Dreiecke, Rauten, Kreisel, .... die Graphik ist stark reduziert, dadurch aber auch leicht erfassbar. Jede Form bewegt sich anders und hat andere Fähigkeiten, auf die man sich einstellen muss. Es gibt zwei Möglichkeiten, Feinden zu entgehen: Ausweichen und Ballern. Am besten gleichzeitig mit einem "twin stick" Controller, z.B. von Microsoft. Mit Maus und Tastatur ist man in vielen Leveln sonst einfach aufgeschmissen.  

Genial ist das Score-System: Um einen Level erfolgreich zu bewältigen, muss i.d.R. ein bestimmter Mindest-Score erreicht werden. Gegner bringen beim Abschiessen Punkte für den Score, und hinterlassen für ein paar Sekunden lang "geoms", die man aufsammeln kann. Damit erhöht sich der Multiplikator für die Punkte. 
Um den Score für jeden Level zu verbessern, muss man also sowohl ständig Gegner abballern, als auch Geoms aufsammeln. Umso mehr, als jede Berührung mit Gegnern kritisch für einen ist, d.h. man muss zwar Geoms aufsammeln, aber sonst allem ausweichen.... Man ist also ganz schön beschäftigt. 

Das Spiel hat ein sehr hohes Tempo, sehr flüssige Graphik und schöne Kontraste und Effekte. Dadurch kommt man schnell in einen meditativen Spielfluss. Die Level sind schwierig, man kann aber unbegrenzt oft (und sehr schnell) wiederholen, so dass sich die Frustration anfangs in Grenzen hält. Dazu später. 

Ich spiele derzeit bevorzugt Geometry Wars 3, obwohl ich Witcher 3 und ein paar andere Games noch fast ungespielt im Account habe. GW3 hat drei entscheidende Vorzüge: 
1. Es ist sehr schnell erlernbar. Man muss keine Handbücher lesen und keine In-game Tutorials absolvieren. Einfach starten und fast alles andere ist intuitiv. 
2. Egal, ob man gerade nur 5 Minuten oder eine Stunde Zeit hat - GW3 kann man schnell starten, spielen, und auch schnell wieder aufhören. 
3. Erfahrungspunkte, Guides und In-game equipment sind fast völlig unwichtig, bei GW3 zählt Skill: und zwar Reaktion, Voraussicht und Taktik. 

Leider zeigt mir das Spiel auch auf, dass ich kein Teenager mehr bin. In vielen Situationen ist meine Reaktionszeit einfach nicht mehr ausreichend - bei den meisten Level ist eine "Drei Sterne" Punktzahl für mich beim ersten Anlauf fast immer unerreichbar, und "Adventure" Level 50 habe ich bisher noch gar nicht geschafft. Von daher ist abzusehen, dass ich irgendwann GW3 wieder entsage und mich wieder ruhigeren Games zuwenden werde :-)

15642978.review:
Without a doubt, the best twin stick shooter ever made. There, I said it. This game has usurped Super Stardust HD’s throne. The various drones and supers you can upgrade create a variety and freedom of choice unparalleled in any other twin stick. The developers have clearly gone back to the drawing board again and again to wring out every possible level variety they could imagine – you will not find the same basic arena over and over in this game, no siree. Enemy variety is abundant enough, as well – you will learn to hate some and taunt others. Plus, boss fights! 

I admit, I was frustrated with the level progression until they nerfed it in a recent patch, and now the game is perfect. There is massive replay potential in the variety of loadouts you can choose, and going for three stars in every level will keep you challenged for a long while. I haven’t even tried the co-op yet – looking forward to it. Not to mention, the graphics are gorgeous – pay close attention as the levels morph into gridlined 3D maps at every start. The music is pure pulse-pounding techno goodness, as glittery as the neon-soaked graphics.  This game oozes polish. 

To top it with a cherry, the devs have thrown in modes that ape the previous entries in the series all for free, basically giving you the entire series in one game. How cool is that?  

If you are new to twin stick shooters, look no further. If you are fan of the series already, you must be playing it right now rather than reading this. 

This is the best shooter on Steam. Hearing that robotic voice intone “bonfire” as you grab a super and hose off every enemy on the screen into neon shards is one of the most satisfying moments in instant-gratification gaming ever.  Enjoy!

3分以内、残機1など様々な条件でのモードで、敵を殲滅しながらハイスコアを目指すことになる。スクロール型ではなく一定の範囲で戦うタイプ。
立方体をステージとする新しいステージだけでなく、今までどおりの平面ステージやルールも収録され、決定版と言える出来。
オンラインリーダーボードもあり。フレンドがいればPinballFXのように点数を競える。
ロードやリトライなどのシステム面も完璧な出来。画面効果は最低にしたほうが視認性が良い。箱コン対応
[h1]-------今作はここが違う-------[/h1]
・今作の特徴は頭を混乱させる多次元化。ディメンションのその名の通り立方体や球体を舞台として戦うことになる。
昔のゲームのように逃げたはずの敵が1周回って後ろから攻撃してくるなんてことが多いので非常に難易度が上がっている。
つまり、角に逃げる戦法が通じないステージがある。360度逃げ場なし。視野の悪い曲がり角から敵が来ることも危険だ
・全50面からなるアドベンチャーモードのボスが非常に楽しい。ほぼ10面ごとにデカイボスが配置されているのだが、一筋縄ではいかないボスばかり
ボス戦まで遠く出現させるのが面倒だが、ボス戦にはそれだけの興奮と価値がある。きちんと倒し方を学び組み立てないといけない。
もちろんボス戦もオンラインリーダーボードがあり、点数を競うためにはボスを殺さず攻撃の嵐を避け続ける必要がある。
まだノーマル40面で詰まっているのにハードコア20面とウルティメイト40面が存在。とんでもないボリューム。
[h1]------各モードについておおまかに------[/h1]
・アドベンチャー　ハードコア　ウルティメイト　ボーナス
各面で一定のルールに従いクリアし、点数によって手に入る星を集めながら進めていく
クラシックに採用されているルールで平面、球体、立方体、ドーナツ型など様々なステージで戦うことになる
しかし必然的に似たようなことの繰り返しになるためやや疲れる
・クラシック
2以前の基本形態を再現したモード。平面ステージ
デッドライン、キング、エヴォルヴド、パシフィズム、ウェーブ、レトロエヴォルヴドを収録
デッドライン　3分以内で点数を競う。残機無限
キング　ステージに配置された円のなかでしか攻撃できず、円が次々に消滅出現を繰り返す
エヴォルヴド　残機3でスコアを競うモード
パシフィズム　攻撃不可1機のみ。ステージに配置されたゲートを通過すると少範囲の爆発が起こりそれでスコアを競う
ウェーブ　残機1で敵の波をくぐり抜けていくモード。突撃型の敵が編隊を組んで襲い掛かってくる
レトロエヴォルヴド　残機3でスコアを競うモード。初代の再現

15266535.review:
I consider this the pinnacle of twin-stick arcade shooters. I go on benders with this game so long that the brightly colored shapes burn into my brain and I see them behind closed eyelids. I've been a fan of the series since the first one (the mini-game) and watched it grow, and this iteration is leagues ahead of its predecessors as well as any similar titles you might find on Steam. The production values are top-notch and the gameplay is finely tuned and addictive & varied enough to keep you playing for hours and coming back for more. From the slick menus to the creative, psychedelic 3-dimensional level designs and variety of ways to approach them, it's clear the developers put a lot of love and effort into this. However, what impressed me most wasn't the polished presentation, but rather the variations on the basic types of gameplay modes and how they translate over to 3 dimensions. There are still flat-surfaced levels, but on the 3D stages, you (and your enemies, the types and behaviors of which are vast) have command of the entire surface which is sometimes covered with stragetically placed walls and other interactive objects. This opens up worlds of new possibilities, and the developers clearly explored a large amount of them. In fact, a recent free update (in which "Evolved" was added to the game's subtitle) introduced even more level designs. With the attention to detail and sheer amount of gameplay elements - some of which are continually being added - you really get the feeling that this is a labor of love for the folks at Sierra.

I'd like to address a very common complaint I've noticed: the difficulty. When I first started playing this, I agreed that it was insanely difficult and the learning curve too steep, but after spending a few hours with it, I felt increasingly comfortable and began to advance quite quickly through the adventure mode. In fact, a few days after getting this, I revisited those early stages I initially had so much trouble with and wound up getting the full 3 star score on all of them with relative ease. It's true that the amount of enemies on screen at one time and the frantic pace at which the game operates can be extremely overwhelming to people not used to it (as can the cheesy techno soundtrack), but it is not impossible. If you have at least decent hand-eye coordination and a twin-stick controller (and I cannot stress how important it is to use a modern, dual analog stick controller like the Xbox 360's with this game), rest assured, you'll get the hang of it. And this is one game most definitely worth getting the hang of.
